items.content:
Introduction

What do you know about England, the English language and English people?
Maybe a lot and maybe not so much. No worries!
In each theme you will learn something more about English life and culture.

Ready to start?

Life and Culture

In each 'Life and Culture' block you will visit the webpage of the Woodlands Junior School. They have written a website on everyday life in the United Kingdom.
In each theme, you will read about a different topic.
In this theme, the first thing you do is go on a virtual tour of the
Woodlands Junior School.

During the tour, try to answer the questions below.

Remember to put the score into your work plan.

prompt.body: In which year did they build the school?
How old do you think the children are at Junior School?
Which of these statements is true?

content.body: At Woodlands children always work on the computer.
At Woodlands every classroom has got an interactive whiteboard.
At Woodlands there are musical instruments in every classroom.

prompt.body: How many computers are in the computer room?
Which of these statements is true?

content.body: The children get their books at the city library.
There is only one library in the school.
There is a small library in every classroom.

prompt.body: Who can go into the staffroom?

items.content:
God save the Queen

In the United Kingdom they have a Queen. We have a King now.
They sing about the Queen in their national anthem.
Click on the icon below to listen to the anthem.

God save our gracious ...1... ,
Long live our ...2... Queen,
...3... save the Queen:
Send her ...4... ,
Happy and glorious,
Long to ...5... over us:
God save the Queen.

Copy the text and paste it in a Worddocument.
Fill in de text one of the following words at the open spaces.

a reign d Queen
b noble e God
c victorious

Greeting Etiquette
The text below is about the way British people greet each other.
Read the text and answer the questions below.

How to Greet someone in Britain

The Handshake
A handshake is the most common form of greeting among the English and British people and is customary (gewoon) when you are introduced to somebody new.

The Kiss
It is only when you meet friends, whom you haven't seen for a long time, that you would kiss the cheek of the opposite sex. In Britain one kiss is generally enough.

Formal greetings
The usual formal greeting is a 'How do you do?' and a firm handshake, but with a lighter touch between men and women.
'How do you do?' is a greeting not a question and the correct response is to repeat 'How do you do?' You say this when shaking hands with someone.

'How are you?' is a question and the most common and polite response is "I am fine thank you and you?"
Nice to meet you ��" Nice to meet you too.
Delighted to meet you��" Delighted to meet you too.
Pleased to meet you ��" Pleased to meet you too.
Glad to meet you - Glad to meet you too.
Good Morning / Good Afternoon / Good Evening

Informal greetings
Hi - Hi or hello
Morning / Afternoon / Evening ( We drop the word 'Good' in informal situations).
How's you? - Fine thanks. You?
Thank you / thanks / cheers
We sometimes say 'cheers' instead of thank you.
You may hear 'cheers' said instead of 'good bye', what we are really saying is 'thanks and bye'.

  • Remember the score to put into your work plan.


Bron: Woodland Junior School

prompt.body: All people greet each other with a kiss.
If people kiss as a greeting …

content.body: They give each other 1 kiss on the cheek.
They give each other 3 kisses on the cheek.

prompt.body: When people greet each other they always say 'Nice to meet you'.
If someone says 'How do you do' you answer with:
Hi and Hello are examples of informal greetings.
Instead of "Thanks, and goodbye" people sometimes say "Cheers".

items.content:
Small talk

If you make small talk, you talk to someone about the weather or something else that is not very important. Most of the time small talk is with strangers.


You are now going to watch a scene with some small talk in it.
After watching the video, answer the questions below.

  • Don't forget to put your score into your work plan.

content.body: He thinks the moose is talking to him.

prompt.body: What is the topic of their small talk?

items.content:
The last 5 minutes of every lesson ...........

  • Have you filled in your workplan yet?
  • Write down in your notebook what went right and what was difficult.
  • Did you learn new words? If so, are they already in your notebook, to learn at home.
  • Continue with Duolingo.

• Rehearse all words and chunks of Personal
  • Rehearse all grammar of Personal - also see the study planner Grammar in Magister
